OLD MANUSCRIPT DISCOVERED
Freshman Editor Fabricates Interesting
Story to Show Eternity of College
Traditions—Dr. Powell Pleads
Innocent.

Dr. Chilton L. Powell, instructor of English, who has lately been
engaged in the study of university
life in merry England, has discovered a hitherto unpublished manuscript of Sir Walter Scott, written in his student days at Oxford.
The circumstances connected
with this discovery are quite remarkable. A friend of Dr. Powell's, a student at Oxford, while
engaged in cleaning out the garrett of one of the old buildings
there, happened upon an ancient
ale cask, filled, to his disappoint,inent, with papers. Knowing of
the researches of our instructor,
he shipped the cask, collect, to
Baltimore as a Christmas present.
In going through its contents, Dr.
Powell found the manuscript in
a bundle with nearly a dozen letters from various ma.gazine editors of that day.
The manuscript is of some
length. It deals with the romance
of an Oxford student of the days
of good Queen Bess, giving an accurate picture of the University
life of the period. The brief extract following, written in 'the
now famous novelist's most vigorous style, shows that time has
little changed some customs.
"Alia, wretch, tlioughtest thou
it hit me? Ay, marry, take that!"
As Michael threw the chalk the
door opened and the old warden
entered to wash off the blackboards.
"I pray you, masters, scatter
not that chalk upon the floor. Forsooth, the Dean forbids it."
"How now, good Henry, mar
thou not our noble pastime; spoil
not our just sport. Nay, by my
halidome, methinks thy presence
ist undesirable, thou cracked-brain

varlet."
This from Jack Foster:
"Please you, gentles." The rest
was lost in old Henry's rapid exit.
The battle continued,erasers being
added to the missiles already flying about the apartment.
The sound of breaking glass was
heard. The door again opened, aild
the wise professor appeared.
"So! Fie, fie! Is this the low
employment to which hath fallen
the worthy product of the cliffs of
Dover? By my Cicero, I fear me
truly we shall have to purchase a
privy safe of iron and put our
chalk and erasers under padlock
and key, else certes, you all must
needs bid your caution money,
farewell! But grammercy, boys
will be boys. On with our
Chaucers."
Incidentally, Dr. Powell denies
any knowledge whatsoever of the
discovery.

The Time is Ripe.
If there is one non-war problem that the student body of Hopkins
should decide this spring it is the question of undergraduate athletics.
The pros and cons have thrashed out the issues of this problem for
many long years. But, for all those years, the issue was an academic,
theoretical, untried issue. Filially, we have been privileged to see the
day when the undergraduate athletics problem has undergone the acid
test of practical experience. When the demand for a vote on the question was made in past years the "old guard" of our beneficient and paternal athletic association told us that "the time had not come," that
"the scheme is impractical under present conditions."
But now the time has come—the time for deciding the question of
undergraduate athletics is here. The athletic record of the present
year—the results of which can be fairly judged at the present time—is
an eloquent and undeniable plea for undergraduate athletics. If ever
Hopkins boasted a successful football season it was last fall—
"Charley" Brickley's team to the contrary notwithstanding. We won
just one game, it is true; but for the first time we had a football team
that battled over every inch of ground, that came out of a game with
tears streaming down its cheeks, that fought rather for the honor of
its Alma Mater than for personal amusement or outdoor exercise.
When they won they celebrated a real victory; when they lost they
felt the sting of defeat they cared.
During the entire football season last fall six graduate students
played with the team. In any one game there were never any more
than three graduates; in many there were less. To each one of those
men—Sadler, Sheffey, McKeithen, Hearn, Montgomery and Purcell—
we owe sincere gratitude and unstinted praise. They were not begged,
not even asked to help the team; they came out of their own accord
and worked for the positions they won. But we must not allow our appreciation and gratitude to cloud the issue. It was demonstrated last
fall that Hopkins could turn out an undergraduate team that would
not bring discredit to the University. Graduate students have to sacrifice valuable time and important work to engage regularly in athletics.
The faculty discourages and disapproves the participation of graduates
in athletics.
The experience of the spring teams bears out our contention. The
lacrosse team, which boasts the highest standards and the best record
of any Hopkins team, has not a single graduate student on the squad.
The baseball team has in its line-up two graduate students whose positions might without any real detriment be filled by any one of a number of undergraduates; the track team has among its own number two
faithful graduates who would gladly be relieved by less busy undergraduates.
If we are going to continue athletics in war times when every institution must stand the test of necessity, let us adopt a system of athletics by which the greatest number, the youngest, the least developed
students are attracted to the several branches of athletics. In these
times the physique of every individual college man—not the size of
gate receipts—is the measure of the success of an athletic system.
Now is the time for Hopkins to shed its antiquated, inefficient, halfway athletic policy, and to adopt an athletic policy that will at one
time serve the best interests of the country and those of the University.
The time is ripe for the undergraduate student body to rise up and
demand its long-desired, but inherent right—undergraduate athletics.

A Hopkins Tradition in Danger.
Hopkins is proud of its scholastic ideals and achievements; Hopkins
is proud of the great men that have taught and those that have learned
within its walls; so is Hopkins proud of the lacrosse teams that have
represented it on the athletic field. In lacrosse, a game of science,
skill and endurance, Hopkins has always excelled. Lacrosse trophies
and championships come to Hopkins as regularly as commencement
(lays. Harvard and Yale may have had their football, track or crew
championships; Hopkins has had even more regularly its lacrosse
championship.
It was therefore with no cursory feeling of regret, but with a deep,
profound feeling of loss, that every Hopkins man saw the Varsity for

In the destruction of the buildings at Homewood of the Johns
Hopkins University on March 27
much of the credit for the success
of the "White" army is due the
raiding patrol, which bombed the
buildings. PrivateW.T.Tibbets,a
member of this patrol, has consented to the publication of the
following account of the raid:
"Corporal Sickel, Privates Littman and Welliver and I got in
the express wagon on York road
and covered up with the bedding
which was in the wagon, the other
three lying lengthwise in the wagon and I lying across the back.
When the wagon reached the Hopkins Bowl, the guard stopped it,
looked in and jammed the butt of
his rifle into the bedding to see if
it Avas all right; then he let us
pass. The first time the rifle hit •
me on the knee, and the second
time in the stomach.
"'Wlwit we reached the Gilman
Hall tunnel, we entered unobserved by way of the postoffice,
and went around to the rear of
the building. Here Corporal Sickel left a paper bomb, on which it
was stated that the bomb would
go off at 3.45 P. M. It was then
3.40; that gave us five minutes to
get out of the building.
"Then we went into the washroom by Dr. Hulburt's office,
jumped out the window, tore off
the tunnel covering and got into
tile tunnel. It was pitch dark;
and, as I was somewhat familiar
with the tunnel, I led the way.
When we turned into the tunnel
connecting the Civil Engineering and Mechanical Engineering
Buildings, I saw a faint light coiling from the cellar of the Civil
Engineering Building.
"When we had nearly reached
it, we heard steps; and, on peeping around the corner, we saw two
men of the 'Brown' army approaching. They must live heard
us, for they turned the lights out
and waited. But we out-waited
them; and in a few minutes the
lights went on and they advanced.
We captured ;hem, Corporal Sickel placing Littman and me as
guards over them while he placed
a bomb in the Civil Engineering
Building.
"The two prisoners were Sergeant Townsend and Private Jammer. Suddenly, Townsend made
a leap at me, and I pulled the
trigger; and while I was cocking
my rifle, he grabbed it and we
had a tussel. Jammer also jumped
on me; but Littman shot him
twice, and then shot Townsend
twice. Just then the light went

out; and Littman and I ran down
the tunnel.
"When we.reached the Mechanical Engineering Building, Littman went on to the powerhouse,
while I prepared a bomb for the
former. Just as I was about to
plant my bomb, I looked up and
saw a figure between me and the
light. I knew he could not see
me; so I waited for him to go.
Since I had lost my gun in the
fight in the tunnel, I was in a
tight place; but I grew tired of
waiting, and decided to bluff this
guard. So I called out:
"'Say! I've had a bead on you
and could have plugged you for
the last ten minutes. You, can't
see me, though. Now, put down
your gun and walk up to the other
end of the building!'
"He did as I directed; and I
crept out and followed the tunnel to the manhole near the Hopkins Club, where I waited until
the building was taken by Lieutenant Eby, then I blew it up and
later joined my company." ,

Freshman Editor Fabricates Interesting
Story to Show Eternity of College
Traditions—Dr. Powell Pleads
Innocent.

Dr. Chilton L. Powell, instructor of English, who has lately been
engaged in the study of university
life in merry England, has discovered a hitherto unpublished manuscript of Sir Walter Scott, written in his student days at Oxford.
The circumstances connected
with this discovery are quite remarkable. A friend of Dr. Powell's, a student at Oxford, while
engaged in cleaning out the garrett of one of the old buildings
there, happened upon an ancient
ale cask, filled, to his disappoint,inent, with papers. Knowing of
the researches of our instructor,
he shipped the cask, collect, to
Baltimore as a Christmas present.
In going through its contents, Dr.
Powell found the manuscript in
a bundle with nearly a dozen letters from various ma.gazine editors of that day.
The manuscript is of some
length. It deals with the romance
of an Oxford student of the days
of good Queen Bess, giving an accurate picture of the University
life of the period. The brief extract following, written in 'the
now famous novelist's most vigorous style, shows that time has
little changed some customs.
"Alia, wretch, tlioughtest thou
it hit me? Ay, marry, take that!"
As Michael threw the chalk the
door opened and the old warden
entered to wash off the blackboards.
"I pray you, masters, scatter
not that chalk upon the floor. Forsooth, the Dean forbids it."
"How now, good Henry, mar
thou not our noble pastime; spoil
not our just sport. Nay, by my
halidome, methinks thy presence
ist undesirable, thou cracked-brain

varlet."
This from Jack Foster:
"Please you, gentles." The rest
was lost in old Henry's rapid exit.
The battle continued,erasers being
added to the missiles already flying about the apartment.
The sound of breaking glass was
heard. The door again opened, aild
the wise professor appeared.
"So! Fie, fie! Is this the low
employment to which hath fallen
the worthy product of the cliffs of
Dover? By my Cicero, I fear me
truly we shall have to purchase a
privy safe of iron and put our
chalk and erasers under padlock
and key, else certes, you all must
needs bid your caution money,
farewell! But grammercy, boys
will be boys. On with our
Chaucers."
Incidentally, Dr. Powell denies
any knowledge whatsoever of the
discovery.

The Time is Ripe.
If there is one non-war problem that the student body of Hopkins
should decide this spring it is the question of undergraduate athletics.
The pros and cons have thrashed out the issues of this problem for
many long years. But, for all those years, the issue was an academic,
theoretical, untried issue. Filially, we have been privileged to see the
day when the undergraduate athletics problem has undergone the acid
test of practical experience. When the demand for a vote on the question was made in past years the "old guard" of our beneficient and paternal athletic association told us that "the time had not come," that
"the scheme is impractical under present conditions."
But now the time has come—the time for deciding the question of
undergraduate athletics is here. The athletic record of the present
year—the results of which can be fairly judged at the present time—is
an eloquent and undeniable plea for undergraduate athletics. If ever
Hopkins boasted a successful football season it was last fall—
"Charley" Brickley's team to the contrary notwithstanding. We won
just one game, it is true; but for the first time we had a football team
that battled over every inch of ground, that came out of a game with
tears streaming down its cheeks, that fought rather for the honor of
its Alma Mater than for personal amusement or outdoor exercise.
When they won they celebrated a real victory; when they lost they
felt the sting of defeat they cared.
During the entire football season last fall six graduate students
played with the team. In any one game there were never any more
than three graduates; in many there were less. To each one of those
men—Sadler, Sheffey, McKeithen, Hearn, Montgomery and Purcell—
we owe sincere gratitude and unstinted praise. They were not begged,
not even asked to help the team; they came out of their own accord
and worked for the positions they won. But we must not allow our appreciation and gratitude to cloud the issue. It was demonstrated last
fall that Hopkins could turn out an undergraduate team that would
not bring discredit to the University. Graduate students have to sacrifice valuable time and important work to engage regularly in athletics.
The faculty discourages and disapproves the participation of graduates
in athletics.
The experience of the spring teams bears out our contention. The
lacrosse team, which boasts the highest standards and the best record
of any Hopkins team, has not a single graduate student on the squad.
The baseball team has in its line-up two graduate students whose positions might without any real detriment be filled by any one of a number of undergraduates; the track team has among its own number two
faithful graduates who would gladly be relieved by less busy undergraduates.
If we are going to continue athletics in war times when every institution must stand the test of necessity, let us adopt a system of athletics by which the greatest number, the youngest, the least developed
students are attracted to the several branches of athletics. In these
times the physique of every individual college man—not the size of
gate receipts—is the measure of the success of an athletic system.
Now is the time for Hopkins to shed its antiquated, inefficient, halfway athletic policy, and to adopt an athletic policy that will at one
time serve the best interests of the country and those of the University.
The time is ripe for the undergraduate student body to rise up and
demand its long-desired, but inherent right—undergraduate athletics.

out the real value and the absolute necessity for a positive, aggressively rigid system of undergraduate athletics. If the General Athletic

In the destruction of the buildings at Homewood of the Johns
Hopkins University on March 27
much of the credit for the success
of the "White" army is due the
raiding patrol, which bombed the
buildings. PrivateW.T.Tibbets,a
member of this patrol, has consented to the publication of the
following account of the raid:
"Corporal Sickel, Privates Littman and Welliver and I got in
the express wagon on York road
and covered up with the bedding
which was in the wagon, the other
three lying lengthwise in the wagon and I lying across the back.
When the wagon reached the Hopkins Bowl, the guard stopped it,
looked in and jammed the butt of
his rifle into the bedding to see if
it Avas all right; then he let us
pass. The first time the rifle hit •
me on the knee, and the second
time in the stomach.
"'Wlwit we reached the Gilman
Hall tunnel, we entered unobserved by way of the postoffice,
and went around to the rear of
the building. Here Corporal Sickel left a paper bomb, on which it
was stated that the bomb would
go off at 3.45 P. M. It was then
3.40; that gave us five minutes to
get out of the building.
"Then we went into the washroom by Dr. Hulburt's office,
jumped out the window, tore off
the tunnel covering and got into
tile tunnel. It was pitch dark;
and, as I was somewhat familiar
with the tunnel, I led the way.
When we turned into the tunnel
connecting the Civil Engineering and Mechanical Engineering
Buildings, I saw a faint light coiling from the cellar of the Civil
Engineering Building.
"When we had nearly reached
it, we heard steps; and, on peeping around the corner, we saw two
men of the 'Brown' army approaching. They must live heard
us, for they turned the lights out
and waited. But we out-waited
them; and in a few minutes the
lights went on and they advanced.
We captured ;hem, Corporal Sickel placing Littman and me as
guards over them while he placed
a bomb in the Civil Engineering
Building.
"The two prisoners were Sergeant Townsend and Private Jammer. Suddenly, Townsend made
a leap at me, and I pulled the
trigger; and while I was cocking
my rifle, he grabbed it and we
had a tussel. Jammer also jumped
on me; but Littman shot him
twice, and then shot Townsend
twice. Just then the light went

out; and Littman and I ran down
the tunnel.
"When we.reached the Mechanical Engineering Building, Littman went on to the powerhouse,
while I prepared a bomb for the
former. Just as I was about to
plant my bomb, I looked up and
saw a figure between me and the
light. I knew he could not see
me; so I waited for him to go.
Since I had lost my gun in the
fight in the tunnel, I was in a
tight place; but I grew tired of
waiting, and decided to bluff this
guard. So I called out:
"'Say! I've had a bead on you
and could have plugged you for
the last ten minutes. You, can't
see me, though. Now, put down
your gun and walk up to the other
end of the building!'
"He did as I directed; and I
crept out and followed the tunnel to the manhole near the Hopkins Club, where I waited until
the building was taken by Lieutenant Eby, then I blew it up and
later joined my company." ,

Dr. Latane Makes 0. D. K. Oration.

At the annual public initiation
of the Omicron Delta Kappa Society of Washington and Lee University on last Thursday, Dr. John
H. Latane, professor of American
history at Hopkins and formerly
head of the department of history
at Washington and Lee, spoke before a large audience on "The Tradition of American Isolation."
Dr. Latane traced the theory of
aloofness from international affairs on the part of the United
States from Washington's first administration to the outbreak of
the present world war. He justified America's entrance into the
war and approved the abandonment of the historic dogma of the
Monroe Doctrine. "Monroe attempted to make the Western
Hemisphere safe for democracy,"
said the speaker, "and President
Wilson wants to make the world,
safe for democracy."
